Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: FIDO - Facilitating Interaction for Dogs with Occupations: Wearable computing for two-way communication with assistance dogs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Assistance dogs have improved the lives of thousands of people with disabilities. Guide dogs, service dogs, and hearing dogs can provide independence and significantly enhance quality of life. However, communication between human and canine partners is currently limited. Handlers give commands, and dogs respond with behaviors, which can sometimes have ambiguous meanings to the handlers. For example, a guide dog stops while walking with his handler, but the dog has no definitive way to tell the handler there is a new barrier on a familiar path. A hearing dog alerts his handler, but can't easily report that the fire alarm has sounded and they need to evacuate. A service dog may need to receive a "lie down" command silently in a dark, crowded theater, or from a distance, which would preclude verbal or hand signals. The PI's goal in this research is to explore fundamental aspects of wearable technologies to support two-way communication between assistance dogs and their handlers. To this end, the PI will investigate on-body interfaces for dogs in the form of electronic textiles and computers integrated into assistance dog clothing, such as vests and harnesses. Studies will assess the abilities of dogs to interact with affordances worn on their bodies, and determine what stimuli dogs can sense and comprehend from wearable technology. The work will be divided into three thrusts: Dog-to-handler communication (to determine to what extent dogs can activate affordances on their harnesses, vests, coats, or collars, such as "touch points" which can be activated by a dog's nose touch, and "pull points" which can be activated by tugging); Handler-to-dog communication (to investigate the sensory capabilities of dogs to respond to simple stimuli incorporated into a dog vest or harness, such as small vibrating motors); Handler feedback and control (the team will implement a head-mounted visual and/or auditory display to allow handlers to receive input from their dogs, as well as control interfaces that can be integrated into a harness handle, leash, or a piece of clothing worn by the handler). Design and testing of the on-body interfaces for the dogs will be carried out using an iterative approach, and the final designs will be validated with three assistance-trained dogs in laboratory and real-world environments. The PI will also stress-test the designs with dogs at speed on an obstacle course.

Broader Impacts: Project outcomes will extend the state of the art in wearable interfaces to animals, and will contribute pioneering work to the nascent fields of Animal Computer Interfaces and Inter-species Interaction, as well as discovering more about the physical and cognitive abilities of dogs. Adapting usability analysis and design techniques from the human realm to apply to animals will expand the body of knowledge in Interactive Computing. In addition to the direct impact of improving the quality of life for people with disabilities, the technologies developed in this project could have application to other working dog teams (e.g., in military or police canine units, and in search and rescue), and they may ultimately allow all pet owners to better communicate with and train their dogs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FIDO project team researched fundamental aspects of wearable technologies to support two-way communication between working dogs and their handlers.  For example, FIDO technology allows a medical alert dog to call 911 with a GPS location when his human partner has a seizure.  It allows a hearing service dog to notify his deaf owner what specific sound he just heard - such as a tornado siren.  It also allows a Search and Rescue dog working a mile away from his handler to get vibration cues to know what direction to search, and allows the dog to alert when he has found his target without having to return to his handler.

Working with assistance dog professionals, the FIDO project team created wearable electronics integrated into assistance dog clothing, such as vests, coats, sleeves, collars, and harnesses.  The interfaces were based on the natural abilities of dogs: tugging, biting, holding, and touching with the nose. The team built nine different sensor designs and tested them with fourteen dogs of different breeds to determine the most effective and reliable interfaces, and where to place them on the dog's body for easiest access.  A capacitive sensor mounted on the ribcage was the best interface with the least accidental activations.

The FIDO team also investigated collar-worn Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) that detect dog movements.  This allows dogs to perform certain behaviors, or "gestures" (such as spinning), to communicate rather than activating a sensor on their vest.  The study included three dogs that were trained to perform a gesture behavior upon encountering a particular street sign, simulating a guide dog scenario.  The FIDO team also created a guide dog harness that provides vibrotactile feedback to a visually impaired handler, allowing a dog to warn his owner about obstacles in their path.  The team also performed studies of passive monitoring, examining if the IMUs can help to determine stress levels of dogs in kennels. 

Handler-to-dog communication experiments included a bodysuit that incorporated vibrating motors to allow handlers to send "haptic", or touch, commands to the dog.  We experimented with eleven dogs of different breeds to determine the levels of vibration power and frequency that dogs with different coat and body types can best detect and respond to.  The FIDO team trained three dogs to respond to four different vibrotactile cues with behaviors to demonstrate that the dogs can discriminate vibrations and interpret them as commands.  

The FIDO team also performed a preliminary study of touchscreens for in-home medical alert dogs. They applied human-computer interaction theory to show that human modeling methods (such as Fitts' law) hold for dogs also.  

The FIDO project created a number of prototype and demonstration systems, including a Medical Alert vest for an active service dog team, tested in their daily life, that allows the dog to summon help for his disabled handler.  They also created a hearing dog vest that allows a dog to tell his handler if the sound he just heard was a doorbell or a fire alarm.  They also built and tested a Search and Rescue system that allows dogs to indicate when they have found their search target, and a mobile device system that allows the handlers to track their dogs and where they have activated sensors.  

Students were an integral part of the FIDO project, including both undergraduate and graduate students in the research.  The FIDO project research supported three Ph.D.s, six M.S. capstone projects, and two undergraduate theses.  

The results of FIDO research was disseminated in nineteen journal and refereed conference papers. The first FIDO paper won the "Best Paper" award from the International Symposium on Wearable Computing (ISWC).  The team also delivered a TEDx talk, as well as talks at several other universities and a science museum.  FIDO research was featured on many national and local news outlets, including CNN, HLN, Discovery Channel, CBS News, Fox News, NPR, BBC Online, Forbes Magazine, and MIT Technology Review.  

FIDO research significantly contributed to the nascent field of Animal-Computer Interaction, and the team has been active in organizing the new research community.  Allowing working dogs to communicate could be a game-changer to improve quality of life for people with disabilities, and to literally save lives for people with dangerous medical conditions.
